texts.text: So you have multiple users that need to read and write to certain files on the filesystem? This can be done with vsftpd or proftpd quite easily. Let's say you have users called ann, bill and carl and they need to manage files in  /var/www/html . Here's the steps:

texts.text: This makes sure that new files are chmodded as 775 (full read/write for users/group, but only read for everyone else).

texts.label: paragraph

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Modify the users so that their primary group is sharedweb. If you forget this step, when they make new FTP files, they will be owned by each user's primary group (sometimes named the same as the user on some systems) and the permissions will be completeld hosed.
texts.text: Modify the users so that their primary group is sharedweb. If you forget this step, when they make new FTP files, they will be owned by each user's primary group (sometimes named the same as the user on some systems) and the permissions will be completeld hosed.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
usermod -g ann sharedweb
usermod -g bill sharedweb
usermod -g carl sharedweb
texts.text:
usermod -g ann sharedweb
usermod -g bill sharedweb
usermod -g carl sharedweb

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Restart vsftpd to pick up the new configuration and your users should be able upload, delete, and edit each other's files.
